--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> 
> > For our implementation, Philip and I are working
> on a
> > browser-based interface, basically an HTML form in
> > which you select the evolutionary parameters,
> whether
> > or not you want to persist data, which graphical
> > information you want to display during the run,
> etc.  
> >
> 
> This sounds like it will be really cool.  Will
> graphics
> also be displayed in the browser during runtime?

The approach we're taking is to have any additional
graphical information pop up in a new browser window.
For something like an XOR run, you would have
checkboxes for population size, mutation rates, etc. 
And there would also be checkboxes for:

--Fitness graph
--Generational winner topology
--Species makeup of population

If you checked any or all of them, each would pop up
in a new window when you click "Begin Run".  That's
the idea, anyway.  We'll try to make it fairly
flexible, so that the same basic interface may be used
with a variety of different domains.
 
> What if 
> you ran an experiment for example involving
> real-time 
> animations, like Mattias' or Mat's?  

I'm sure it wouldn't be too difficult to display
real-time animations in a seperate window as well. 
We'd like to be able to release our implementation
with at least a couple of different examples, probably
XOR, Tic-Tac-Toe, and perhaps a simple control
experiment in which an agent travels to a target while
avoiding traps.  For this last (and maybe
Tic-Tac-Toe), we'll most likely include a some sort of
real-time visualization.

Derek
